messageBody:
My take is different on this.  I agree with Ted in that I believe that Moira's pronunciation is in the minority, but so what?  I say jettison the rule and stick with phonemic writing.  It causes me no difficulty to read Moira's QS with "It" at the end of words as opposed to "Eat."  She can spell it the way she wants, and I can spell it with "Eat." way. 

I've been reading the QS news with some peculiar spellings such as "jurists" written as "juris"  I want to know what's up with that?  Is that really in the CMU dictionary or is that some peculiarity of the tranliteration program Paul wrote?  The closest dictionary to hand happens to be a Funk & Wagnall's.  The pronunciation shows a "t" at the end of the word.

Paige

Ted Larson Freeman wrote:

Sorry Moira,

That's exactly how I say 'family', and how nearly all Americans say
it. My understanding from the ongoing discussion is that you are
distinctly in the minority in your pronunciation.

In my opinion, this rule needs to be jetisoned.

Ted

> Kingsley Read was specific in his directions - if the syllable is unstressed
